subject: Redfish: Add power metrics for openpower
commitMessage:
Redfish: Add power metrics for openpower

The average and maximum consumed power aggregation history is read and
stored every 30 seconds within an openpower interface per power supply.
This pulls the entire aggregation history for each metric, over all
power supplies, and calculates a total average and maximum.

The total average consumed power is the result from adding the average
of all aggregation history entries per power supply. This is presented
as the `AverageConsumedWatts` in Redfish.

The total maximum consumed power is the result from adding the maximum
value determined from the aggregation history per power supply over the
same aggregation period. This is presented as the `MaxConsumedWatts` in
Redfish.

The `IntervalInMin` Redfish attribute is a single interval(in minutes)
at which all the Redfish power metrics were collected. Therefore, this
interval is set to the highest number of 30 second entries found of
aggregation history up to a 10 minute interval. (The openpower
aggregation history is collected and stored at the same time every 30
seconds, so this interval calculation should not affect the values
presented in Redfish for average and maximum power consumed.)

Tested:
    Used BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG to verify number of method calls
    Used BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG to verify data returned

  "PowerControl": [
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Power#/PowerControl/0",
      "@odata.type": "#Power.v1_0_0.PowerControl",
      "MemberId": "0",
      "Name": "Chassis Power Control",
      "PowerConsumedWatts": 268.0,
      "PowerLimit": {
        "LimitInWatts": 600.0
      },
      "PowerMetrics": {
        "AverageConsumedWatts": 173,
        "IntervalInMin": 10,
        "MaxConsumedWatts": 179
      },
      "Status": {
        "Health": "OK",
        "State": "Enabled"
      }
    }
  ]

Signed-off-by: Matthew Barth <msbarth@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I23e88ef77999ff4da005e5430160f196a9574b46

Patch Set 18:

I ran across this today and saw that it was marked WIP.  Was that intentional?

Patch Set 18:

> I ran across this today and saw that it was marked WIP.  Was that intentional?

Yes. This uses open_power interfaces to retrieve the metrics which were not standardized when implemented and likely wont be since they are power specific. There was also no other place to put this commit at the time other than here for the Witherspoon machine.

Patch Set 18:

Matthew Barth wrote:

> > I ran across this today and saw that it was marked WIP.  Was that intentional?
>
> Yes. This uses open_power interfaces to retrieve the metrics which
> were not standardized when implemented and likely wont be since they
> are power specific. There was also no other place to put this commit
> at the time other than here for the Witherspoon machine.

Thanks Matt.  Should we abandon it now?  Can always reopen later.

Patch Set 18:

> Thanks Matt.  Should we abandon it now?  Can always reopen later.

No. Ideally, this change should be put in the release build location for IBM systems downstream. However, that has the possibility to cause constant cherry-pick/rebasing of this change in bmcweb which is why I believe it was left here at the time.

Patch Set 18:

This change will be re-worked under issue https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1108

Abandoned

This will be re-worked under https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1108
as discussed, the max value needs to come from the max sum of max values taken from the same timestamp
ack, working on it

Done

Doing additional testing while implementing the 10min interval Todd requested.
doesn't this give you the same thing every time through the loop?

Perhaps this is a simplistic question, but I was initially thrown off by having this in a struct, then having logic in the destructor. Does this have something to do with using this PowerMetrics in a lambda down below?

This actually has more to do with the async calls to get the metrics for each power supply. The async lambdas to get each metric are called to get the aggregation history for each power supply. Since its unknown when they'll return, to consolidate each metric correctly across all power supplies this struct is used to do the consolidation per metric when the lambda returns. Once all async call return, this struct is destroyed, therefore that is when the resulting consolidated metric values can be returned in Redfish.
Ack

This through me for a loop, read it wrong.
So, you are adding elements to a maxTotals "array", later on (up there) you are finding the maximum total in that "array" and returning that to Redfish field.
correct, this is to time-align the entries in the aggregation history returned per power supply
Ack

Have I forgotten something here or mixed it up in my head? Is this looking at ps0_input_power and/or ps1_input_power (well, 0 to 9, one to ten) values somewhere? I thought we had some timestamp/average values in one, then timestamp/max in another.

This is for filtering to get only aggregation history from the power supplies (since any object could really implement the aggregation history interface). See line 445

This regex should be producing a filter for `ps*_input_power` where * == to any ps number. (i.e. ps0_input_power, ps10_input_power, ps999_input_power, etc...).
Spinler explained GetSubTree (below), now it makes more sense how you are finding this.

I figured I should ask - is this somehow different than just:
pcJson[][] = *avgMetric

Not sure, I dont see why I couldnt just set them as you suggest. This was a copy/paste from how the power limit was set.

Will switch and check
Done
could probably be a const &?
agreed
Done
Is it possible for maxMetric->size() == 0?  If so, do we need to check for that here?  Not sure what *std::max_element() will be for an empty vector.
yes, and we should hide this entry if that's the case. good catch.

Done

Change made below to skip metric when the vector size is 0.
nit - why in parentheses?
no reason, just a habit of mine. will remove here and on maxHistory.
Done
This removes the excess elements from the end of the vector.  Are those the ones we want to eliminate (oldest?  newest?  Can't happen?)
Correct, the most recent entries are at the front of the array in the aggregation history. So a `resize` trims the appropriate entries off the end so we get down to a 10min interval.
Same question as above re: resize()
See above
Nit: Is there a reason to std::move a built-in type?
I actually did this move since I was moving the int64 out of a tuple. I can remove this.
Done
Why is this needed?  If we are in the method, we already have a this pointer.

Same as the above functions, this follows other areas of the Redfish code that shares ownership of `this` with all that refer to it. I'm hesitant to think its actually required here as it is above for the lambdas, so I'll change.
Done

Not sure I follow this. What "async ones above" are you referring to?

This async is guaranteed to run after those above here in the `doGet` method and the "PowerControl" json entry is created prior to any async call here in the `doGet`. That "PowerControl" json entry is in the response that's given when the PowerMetrics shared object is created within the async below.

Once this GetSubTree async return enters this lambda, that PowerMetrics object is created and the average and maximum functions are called which do their own asyncs to get the data for each power supply.

Done

Shawn and I discussed his concern here. I added the "PowerControl" mandatory attributes within the PowerMetrics to ensure they are set when the metrics are added in case they have not already (i.e. Power limit not enabled, still want power metric data to be added to "PowerControl").
